keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after family members reported he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up' via social media livestream.
Cagle was not armed when arrested but police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle outside the airport.

He faces multiple charges including terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assaults, possession of a firearm in the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.
Cagle has a prior conviction for marijuana possession more than two decades ago and is described as mentally challenged by officials, which authorities say increased the risk of a deadly situation.
The incident is considered a 'tragedy averted' due to early detection by family members and timely law enforcement action.
Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport is the world’s busiest airport, with over 108 million passengers in 2024, making the threat particularly significant on a global scale.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation, underscoring the national security relevance of the event.
Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens emphasized the importance of public vigilance and reporting suspicious behavior, highlighting community involvement in safety.
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem publicly praised law enforcement for preventing harm, connecting the incident to national security messaging.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up' via a social media livestream. Though he was not armed at the time of arrest, police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle. Cagle, a convicted felon with a prior marijuana offense from over 20 years ago, faces multiple charges including terroristic threats and possession of a firearm in the commission of a felony. Authorities say he had already arrived at the airport before 9:30 a.m. and was observed near the TSA check-in area, which is heavily crowded. The incident, which occurred at the world’s busiest airport, was described as a 'tragedy averted' due to early detection and inter-agency cooperation. The FBI is assisting in the investigation, and officials from the Atlanta Mayor and Homeland Security Secretary emphasized the importance of public vigilance and timely reporting to prevent harm. This event underscores the risks associated with firearms, mental health, and public behavior at major transportation hubs.
title: Man Arrested Inside Atlanta Airport After Making Threats to 'Shoot It Up'
